Award.AbstractNarration:
This program will study quasar outflows to test the evolutionary paradigm that links quasars and supermassive black holes to their host galaxies. This will be accomplished via observational and theoretical work on quasar accretion disk outflows that will derive the kinematics, densities, ionization levels, and driving mechanisms of the flows. Elemental abundances in quasar environments will also be addressed, as will the relationship between quasars and host galaxy evolution via use of submillimeter-wavelength measurements.

Broader impacts of the work include research training of undergraduate and graduate students, implementation of a clicker system of classroom response for introductory classes, and public lectures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Quasars provide a unique glimpse into the early evolution of massive galaxies. They represent the most luminous stage(s) of matter accreting onto super-massive black holes (SMBHs) in the centers of these galaxies. An observed correlation between the masses of SMBHs and their surrounding galactic spheroids indicates that SMBH growth is somehow directly linked to the processes of galaxy formation. A paradigm has emerged for linking SMBHs to galaxy evolution that involves major bursts of star formation and quasar activity that together drive blowouts of gas and dust from the galaxies. These blowouts provide a form of “feedback” to the host galaxies that might be essential for regulating both the star formation and SMBH growth during young/active evolution stages, thus producing the SMBH–galaxy mass relation. Quasars are powered by matter heating up as it spirals its way into the SMBHs. This infall forms a disk around the SMBH, called an accretion disk, that glows very brightly and produces powerful winds to drive feedback processes in the surrounding host galaxies. 


Our NSF-funded program was a multifaceted study of the gaseous environments around quasars and the relationships of quasars to galaxy formation and evolution.  We worked specifically on three fronts to examine 1) the energetics and physical properties of quasar accretion-disk outflows that might be the main drivers of feedback in the host galaxies, 2) quasars with red colors caused by dust obscuration because these quasars might identify a particular very early stage of galaxy formation when the galaxies are still dusty before the blowout of gas and dust has fully occurred, and 3) the physical processes of quasar outflows interacting with the host galaxies and the infall of gas from the circum-galactic medium that is expected to feed the bursts of star formation, grow the galaxies, and fuel quasar activity via accretion into the SMBH. 


Our work on this program provided important results to help us piece together the puzzle of quasars in bigger picture of galaxy formation. For example, our analysis of the absorption lines formed in quasar outflows gives us new insights into the physical structure, energetics, and potential impact of quasar outflows on their surrounding galactic environments. We learned that most and perhaps all quasar outflows have enormous columns of gas with very large kinetic energies, consistent with what is needed to drive feedback effects in the galaxies. We also learned that quasar outflows are composed of very tiny clouds with little or no material between them. This surprising result runs against popular models that describe the outflows as smooth continuous streams of gas. The tiny cloud picture requires a different paradigm, most likely involving strong magnetic fields threaded through the accretion disks that can confine the tiny clouds and probably help to accelerate them via centrifugal forces. Another example is our work with data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) that led to the discovery very strong correlations between the amount of reddening/obscuration in quasars and the physical properties of their outflows and accretion disks. These correlations appear to be signatures of quasars evolving from red to blue, e.g., from dusty obscured environments inside young galaxies to older and more quiescent environments of galaxies past their main formation phase. We also discovered a population of extremely red quasars in the SDSS that has a unique suite of properties that altogether appear to identify extreme powerful outflows during a brief young obscured phase of quasar/galaxy evolution.


The broader theme of our research is the exploration of our own origins. We reside in a galaxy that is similar to but much older than the galaxies we study around quasars. Our galaxy does not contain a quasar because the SMBH in our Galactic center is no longer being fed. Quasars mark early phases of galaxy evolution when most of the stars (and planets) in the universe were created, billions of years ago. Our study is one piece of the bigger puzzle of who we are and where we came from. 


It has been an important part of our NSF program to mentor university students in the procedures of science and convey the goals and strategies and results of our research to the general public. Some specific accomplishments include, 1) implementation of a classroom response (“clicker”) system in introductory classes, 2) providing research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, 3) participation in a graduate exchange program with Spain (via the University of Florida’s involvement in the Grand Telescope of the Canaries (GTC), 4) promotion and mentoring of female scientists, 5) bringing our research into the university classroom to provide examples and a context for learning, and 6) public lectures and participation in various outreach programs that introduce the results and methodologies of our research to a large audience.
